questions.uddipok:
Answer the following questions:
(a) What unnecessary things did Jerry do for the authoress?
(b) How would Jerry usually react after getting gifts from the authoress?
(c) Why did Jerry refuse to take money from the authoress to repair the ax handle?
(d) Why was the authoress impressed with Jerry?
(e) Do you like the personality of Jerry? Why?

sub_questions.explanation:
(a) What unnecessary things did Jerry do for the authoress?
In the story, the narrator (the "authoress") purchases a roll-top desk from a junk shop and begins restoring it. While repairing the desk, he finds a secret compartment containing a letter written by Jim Macpherson to his wife, Connie. The narrator then takes the letter to Mrs. Macpherson, believing it to be a meaningful gesture. However, Mrs. Macpherson mistakes him for her late husband, Jim, and is overjoyed to receive the letter. In this context, the "unnecessary" action refers to the narrator's decision to open the desk and read the letter, which was intended to be kept private. While his actions were well-meaning, they were not necessary for Mrs. Macpherson's
(b) How would Jerry usually react after getting gifts from the authoress?
The story does not provide information about Jerry receiving gifts from the authoress. The focus is on the narrator's discovery of the letter and his subsequent visit to Mrs. Macpherson. Therefore, there is no information available regarding Jerry's reactions to receiving gifts.
(c) Why did Jerry refuse to take money from the authoress to repair the ax handle?
The story does not mention any character named Jerry or an incident involving the repair of an ax handle. The narrative centers on the narrator's restoration of the roll-top desk and the discovery of Jim Macpherson's letter. There is no reference to Jerry or an ax handle in the story.
(d) Why was the authoress impressed with Jerry?
As previously mentioned, the story does not feature a character named Jerry. The authoress (the narrator) is impressed by the kindness and love expressed in Jim Macpherson's letter to his wife, Connie. The narrator is moved by the soldiers' temporary truce during World War I and their shared humanity, which is reflected in Jim's letter.(Study Rankers)
(e) Do you like the personality of Jerry? Why?
Since there is no character named Jerry in the story, it is not possible to comment on his personality. However, the narrator's actions demonstrate curiosity, empathy, and a desire to connect with others. These qualities are commendable as they lead to a meaningful interaction with Mrs. Macpherson and the sharing of a poignant story of love and peace.

questions.uddipok:
Write a summary of the following text:
We spend money for different reasons. We buy foods, clothes or everyday essentials, pay for different services, entertain people. travel to places, help others in need or invest in business and thus spend money everyday. In fact, spending is a part of our life. Spending may make us happy or unhappy depending on how and why we spend. When we spend money on things that we need and within our limit, it is good. When it becomes a compulsive behaviour. it makes life stressful. Unnecessary spending or spending beyond one's means has some bad effects. For one thing, it may lead to financial ruin or debt, and for another, it may create unhappiness within families. People who overspend are never satisfied with what they have. They always rush for brands, fashion items, designer clothes etc. Over a period of time it becomes an addiction which may eventually create psychological problems.

sub_questions.explanation: People spend money for various reasons such as buying essentials, paying for services, entertainment, travel, helping others, or investing in business. Spending is a regular part of life and can bring happiness if done wisely and within one’s means. However, compulsive or unnecessary spending can lead to financial problems like debt and cause stress and unhappiness, especially within families. Those who overspend often seek satisfaction through material things like brands and fashion, but this habit can become addictive and may result in psychological issues over time.

Sheikh Saadi, a renowned Persian poet, was travelling to the emperor's palace. Night fell on the way, and the poet took shelter in a courtier's house. As Saadi was dressed in his usual inexpensive attire, the courtier didn’t recognize him. So, he treated the great man with indifference, offering him only a small meal and poor accommodation. On his way back home from the emperor’s palace, Saadi deliberately stopped at the same courtier’s house. This time, however, he was wearing the luxurious clothes given to him by the emperor. Seeing the expensive clothes of the guest, the courtier and his men were extremely hospitable, offering him a spread of fine dishes. During the meal, however, the guest began to put the delicacies into the folds of his fine clothes. Surprised, the courtier asked, "Why are you feeding your clothes, my honorable guest?" Saadi said that his clothes, in fact, deserved the food, reminding the host that last time he was shown poor hospitality because of his ordinary clothes.

questions.uddipok: The graph shows the percentage of different types of books preserved in a college library. Analyze the graph in about 150 words.

sub_questions.explanation:
The bar graph illustrates the percentage of different categories of books preserved in a college library.
According to the graph, science books occupy the highest portion, accounting for 30% of the total collection. This is followed closely by literature books, which make up 25%. Business books come next with 20%, showing that academic and professional disciplines are prioritized in the library's collection.
On the other hand, history and philosophy books constitute only 15%, indicating a relatively lower focus on these subjects. The least represented categories are sports and others, each comprising just 5% of the library’s total books.
Overall, the data suggests that the college library emphasizes science, literature, and business, which may reflect the academic interests or needs of its students and faculty. However, the limited number of books on sports, history, and philosophy implies a potential area for improvement in terms of diversifying the collection to support broader educational needs.

questions.uddipok:
The following is the beginning of a story. Add around 150 words of your won to complete the story:
It was a foggy winter morning. Dr. Rabbi was driving home from hospital after his exhausting overnight shift. Driving was difficult because of the haze. Suddenly, he felt he had driven past somebody sitting by the road. He stopped the car and backed up to see who it was. It was an elderly man, dressed in thin, ragged clothes….

sub_questions.explanation:
The Guardian of the Mist

It was an elderly man, dressed in thin, ragged clothes, shivering uncontrollably against the biting cold. His face was etched with deep lines of exhaustion, and his eyes, though clouded with age, held a desperate flicker of hope as the car’s headlights cut through the mist.
Dr. Rabbi immediately stepped out, the chill of the morning air stinging his skin. "Are you alright, Father?" he asked, his medical instincts overriding his fatigue. The old man tried to speak, but his teeth chattered too violently. He had no shoes, and his hands were purple from the early stages of frostbite.
Without a second thought, the doctor draped his own heavy woollen coat over the man’s shoulders and helped him into the warmth of the passenger seat. As the heater hummed to life, the man whispered that he had lost his way while searching for a nearby clinic. Dr. Rabbi realized that if he hadn't turned back, the man likely wouldn't have survived the morning.
Instead of heading home to sleep, Dr. Rabbi drove to a local shelter, ensuring the man received a hot meal and medical attention. As he finally pulled into his own driveway, the exhaustion was still there, but his heart felt lighter. The foggy morning had reminded him why he became a doctor in the first place: to save lives, even those found by the side of a lonely road.

questions.uddipok: Imaging, you are Lisa/Latif. You have a Facebook friend in Australia. Recently, she/he has shown interest in visiting Bangladesh. Now write a letter to him/her to give him a brief account of the sights and sounds of Bangladesh.

sub_questions.explanation:
Dhaka, Bangladesh 17 August 2025
Dear akbar,
I hope you are doing well. I heard that you are interested in visiting Bangladesh soon, and I am excited to tell you about the beautiful sights and sounds of my country.
Bangladesh is full of natural beauty and vibrant culture. You can explore the serene Sundarbans, the largest mangrove forest in the world, home to the famous Royal Bengal Tigers. The picturesque tea gardens of Sylhet and the peaceful hills of Bandarban offer breathtaking views. The historic city of Paharpur has ancient ruins that tell fascinating stories of our past.
In Dhaka, the bustling streets are alive with colorful rickshaws, street food vendors, and lively markets. You will hear the sounds of traditional music mixed with the chatter of friendly people. Festivals like Pohela Boishakh (Bengali New Year) are celebrated with great enthusiasm, featuring traditional dances, songs, and delicious food.
I am sure your visit will be memorable, full of warm hospitality and wonderful experiences. Please let me know if you need any help planning your trip.
Take care and stay in touch!
Your friend, Latif
